etymologies: late 19th century: earlier denoting a lever apparatus of which one end is raised while the other is lowered, from French (earlier bacule), ‘see-saw’, from battre ‘to bump’ + cul ‘buttocks’

definitions: a type of bridge with a pivoting section that is raised and lowered using counterweights.
shortDefinitions: type of bridge with section which can be raised and lowered using counterweights

definitions: a moveable section of road forming part of a bascule bridge.
shortDefinitions: movable section of road forming part of bascule bridge
